title: 111_hr2110
content: The Act is titled the "Mobile Workforce State Income Tax Fairness and Simplification Act" and limits state withholding and taxation of employee income. The "Mobile Workforce State Income Tax Fairness and Simplification Act" limits state income tax to the employee's residence state and the state where they work for more than 30 days in a calendar year. Wages are only subject to state income tax withholding and reporting if the employee meets these criteria. The "Mobile Workforce State Income Tax Fairness and Simplification Act" states that wages are only subject to state income tax withholding and reporting if the employee is subject to income tax in the state where they work for more than 30 days in a calendar year. Employers can rely on an employee's determination of the time expected to be spent in different states for tax purposes. Employers can rely on an employee's estimate of time spent in different states for tax purposes, as long as there is no fraud or collusion to evade tax. If employer records show employee locations for other business purposes, those can be used for tax obligations. Employers can rely on an employee's estimate of time spent in different states for tax purposes, as long as there is no fraud or collusion to evade tax. Employer records of employee locations for other business purposes do not override an employee's determination. If an employer maintains a time and attendance system tracking employee duties daily, that data should be used instead. The employer can use an employee's estimate of time spent in different states for tax purposes, unless there is fraud. If the employer has a time and attendance system tracking employee duties daily, that data should be used instead of the employee's determination. An employee will be considered present and performing employment duties within a State for a day if the employee performs the preponderance of their employment duties in that State for that day. If an employee performs material employment duties in a resident state and one nonresident state during one day, they will be considered to have performed the preponderance of their employment duties in the nonresident state for that day. For determining an employee's location of performing employment duties, the portion of the day in transit does not apply. The term "employee" is defined by the State where duties are performed, excluding professional athletes. The term "employee" is defined by the State where duties are performed, excluding professional athletes, entertainers, and certain public figures. Professional athletes are individuals who receive wages for performing services in athletic events. Professional athlete is defined as a person who receives wages for services in athletic events. Professional entertainer is defined as a person who receives wages for services in the performing arts. Certain public figures are persons of prominence who perform services. The term "certain public figures" refers to prominent individuals who are paid for services provided at specific events, such as speeches or personal appearances. The term "employer" is defined in accordance with the Internal Revenue Code. The term "time and attendance system" refers to a system where employees must record their work location in real-time. The term "time and attendance system" requires employees to record their work location daily when working outside their primary state, used by the employer to allocate wages across taxing jurisdictions. "Wages or other remuneration" is defined by the state where employment duties are performed. The Act will be effective starting January 1, 2011.
